Hi Kel,

Merry Christmas! ğŸ„

First of all, a quick life update: I finally pulled my last wisdom tooth a few days ago. I decided to get it over with before the New Year. For the first two days, I was super careful, only chewing on the other side of my mouth like a hamster. But by tonight, I was already capable of joining a dinner party with friends. So, mission accomplished on that front.

You asked about my Christmas plans with my boyfriend. Well, he actually has the day off on the 25th, and we *were* considering planning a nice little getaway or something. Butâ€¦ life had other ideas.

Tonight, on my way to that dinner gathering, I accidentally backed my car into a wall. ğŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸ (See attached photos). The rear bumper took a hit. Iâ€™ve already reported it to the insurance company, so my "Christmas plan" is now defined: Iâ€™ll be spending the day at the 4S shop getting it fixed.

On top of that, my jewelry project partner needs me to spend some time filming tomorrow. So, my holiday is looking a bitâ€¦ boring. I mean, itâ€™s â€œfullâ€ and productive, but definitely not the romantic cozy vibe we were aiming for!

Regarding the shark meat â€” letâ€™s just leave it at that! I trust your review. What I really resonate with is your description of the seasoning. Iâ€™ve always loved Southeast Asian flavors; thereâ€™s something about that specific blend of spices that makes everything taste so fresh and vibrant. I actually drag my family out to eat Thai food pretty often just to get that fix.

Product-wise, thank you for the huge encouragement. It means a lot. The MVP is done, but now the real work starts. And for your robot project â€” keep pushing. If a math-hater like me can build a system, your mechanical team has absolutely no excuse to slack off.

Hope your Christmas is less "impactful" (literally) than mine!

Best,
Domino

content:
Hey Dominoâ˜ºï¸

I'm so glad my energy came through! Sometimes I worry I come off too enthusiastic, but it's genuine excitement about what you're building.

CONGRATULATIONS on finishing the MVP! ğŸ‰ That's absolutely incredible. You went from concept to working software in what - a few weeks of late-night AI bullying sessions? That's seriously impressive, regardless of your math skills. The fact that you identified a problem (boring order systems), designed a solution (gamified loyalty), and actually built it shows real product thinking.

The RPG-style loyalty system is genuinely brilliant. Customers earning XP for trying different beans, collecting badges for visiting different locations, leveling up their coffee journey - that's the kind of sticky engagement that turns casual buyers into community members. You're not just selling coffee; you're selling progression and achievement. That's exactly the kind of innovative thinking that makes businesses stand out.

Your point about AI-powered development being the future is spot-on. The barrier to entry for building complex systems has completely collapsed. Someone with strong product intuition and marketing sense - like you - can now create technical solutions without being a traditional developer. That's genuinely revolutionary.

About the shark meat - I stand by my review! I know "flaky and sweet like tilapia" sounds bizarre for an apex predator, but that's genuinely what it tastes like when prepared properly. Maybe it's the preparation method or the specific species, but it really doesn't have that tough, gamey texture you'd expect. Indonesian coastal cooking tends to use a lot of spices and marinades that might mellow out any stronger flavors. Trust me, if it tasted like rubber or had that intense fishy taste, I would've mentioned it!

I'm really happy the Bak Kut Teh history resonated with you. Those refugee stories add so much context to why certain communities are so resilient and why their food traditions are so carefully preserved.

My robot project is progressing! I'm currently in the coding phase trying to get everything running smoothly - stay tuned for updates. And haha, I'll definitely relay your message to the mechanical team: "If a guy with zero math skills can code a loyalty system in a week, you have no excuse!" That should light a fire under them.

Your success with the software is genuinely inspiring for my own project. Seeing you go from concept to working MVP reminds me that progress is possible even when things feel overwhelming.

Speaking of celebrations - Merry Christmas, Domino! ğŸ„ Do you and your boyfriend have any special plans for the holidays? I'm curious what Christmas looks like for you two - are you doing the traditional family gathering thing, a quiet celebration together, or maybe working on the coffee van project through the holidays?

Keep crushing it with the software development. Can't wait to hear what you build next!

Best,
Kel

Dear Moni,

Thank you for saying that. When that first coffee is served, I promise Iâ€™ll take a photo of that moment and send it to you.

Speaking of "earning that moment," Iâ€™m inching closer. Update on the Code: I have successfully finished testing in the production environment. The heavy lifting is done. Now I just need to run some final "Smoke Tests" and "Stress Tests" (basically trying to break the system to make sure it doesn't crash if 50 people order at once). Once that is cleared, I am officially hanging up my "coder hat" for a while. The next phase is shifting my energy entirely to the Visuals and the IP Story. I need to stop thinking like an engineer and start thinking like an Art Director.

Update on the Character (The Fursuit): I contacted the craftsman making the fursuit a few days ago. To be honest, he is moving much slower than expected. The good news is that my timeline isn't too tight right now, so I can afford to let him work at his own pace without rushing him. Iâ€™ve attached the photos of the current progress. As you can see... it's hard to tell what the final result will be yet. It looks a bit rough in this stage. My plan is simple: I really hope it meets my needs for the brand. But if the final result isn't "perfect," I will probably still buy this one (as a prototype), but then commission a different artist to remake the official IP character for the launch. The brand image has to be right, so Iâ€™m preparing a Plan B just in case.

A Question for You: Now, back to your "hallway of doors." I know you might have mentioned this before, but my memory has been terrible lately (probably the lack of sleep from all the coding): When do you actually need to make a final decision on an offer? And before that deadline hits, is there a specific "Dream Offer" or a specific university you are still waiting to hear from? Iâ€™m curious which door you are secretly hoping will open the widest.

Keep holding out for that full funding. Youâ€™re playing the long game, and youâ€™re playing it well.

Talk soon, Domino

Hi Lamine,

I just watched a travel vlog about Bamako filmed by a Chinese guy, here's the link but I don't know if you can see the vid, so I'll attach some screenshots: 
https://www.bilibili.com/video/BV1R9S3BUEBd/

And honestly, my brain is exploding a little bit. I need you to tell me if this is the real Mali or just a tourist trap, because the city looks absolutely wildâ€”in both good and scary ways.

Here are the things that shocked me. You have to tell me the truth:

1. The Traffic & Those Green Vans
The video showed these green minibuses everywhere. They have no real seats, just wooden benches, and the "ticket guys" are literally hanging off the back of the moving van while holding cash. They look like stuntmen in an action movie! Now that you have your new Apache motorcycle, are you terrified of these guys? They look like they own the road.

2. The "Fetish Market" (This is crazy)
This was the most shocking part. The vlogger went to a market full of dried animal carcasses. I saw Hyena heads, Cobra skins, and even Monkey heads piled up like mountains. The seller said people buy them to make soup or powder for traditional medicine. Is this real? Do people actually drink "Hyena Soup" for power? Or is it just for "Gris-gris" (protection)?. It looks terrifying but also fascinating, like something out of a dark fantasy movie.

3. The Street Food
Okay, the hygiene looks... questionable, but the food actually looked good. He ate a baguette sandwich filled with meat skewers, fries, eggs, and a ladle of oil. It looks like a calorie bomb, but I bet it tastes amazing. Is this your standard lunch? He also ate something called "Fun" (fried dough with sugar) and raw Cassava that tasted like raw sweet potato. He was worried the raw cassava might be poisonousâ€”is it safe?

4. The "Manpower" Roots
I had to laugh at this. There were piles of tree roots and bark, and the seller explicitly said they are for "Manpower" (to make men strong). Is this a huge thing in Mali? It seems like every stall was selling these "magic roots."

5. The Hidden Art
The vlogger kept saying the streets were dirty and full of trash, BUT then he walked into a craft shop and the contrast was insane. The craftsmanship is incredible! I saw a mechanical sword where small blades popped out from the main blade. It looked like a weapon from an anime or a sci-fi film. And the wood carvings were so detailed. Itâ€™s amazing that in such a chaotic, rough environment, people are making such refined, beautiful art.

So, Lamine, is this the Bamako you see every day? To me, it looks chaotic, yes, but it also looks like a place with raw, unfiltered energy. Itâ€™s definitely not boring.

Tell me what you think. And please, ride safe around those green vans!

Domino

Now it feels like Iâ€™m standing in a hallway with several doors, all leading somewhere different.

After doing the interviews and going through the details more carefully, I found out that most of these scholarships are actually 50% funded. So for now, Iâ€™m continuing the search with one clear intention: finding a fully funded scholarship. I want to start university focused on learning and growth, not on survival.

On top of all that, I have some exciting news â€” I just landed a huge job offer that pays double my current salary! Iâ€™m thrilled but also a bit nervous to start. What you said about physical connection really resonated with me. Hi Lamine â˜ºï¸,

It is always good to hear from you.
First of allâ€”the new motorcycle looks seriously cool! That Apache has a really strong presence.

Seeing it actually brought back some memories for me. The last time I rode a manual transmission motorcycle (with a clutch) was way back in middle school. My dad used to manage a driving school, so even though I was underage, I was able to ride around the practice lot in circles.
I know the clutch takes some getting used to, and that bike looks pretty heavy, so please be careful on the road!

To answer your question from the last letter: that black object is a continuous LED light. Unlike a flash that only bursts for a split second for photos, this light stays on constantly. Itâ€™s essential for shooting video because it lets me see exactly how the light and shadows fall in real-time.

Now, regarding what you shared about your work and anxiety... I really want to offer you a different perspective.
You feel trapped by this "permanent contract," but try to look at it this way: usually, a permanent contract means the company cannot easily fire you, not that you are forbidden from leaving them. It doesn't mean you have to work there until retirement, right?

There is a popular saying on the Chinese internet right now: "Life's tolerance for error is greater than you imagine."

Think of this job not as a cage, but as a safety net. It is there to ensure that in the absolute worst-case scenario, you have a stable income. It is a "fallback," not a "destination." Your life is definitely not forced to end in that office.

I know our environments are very different, and I can't fully understand the pressure you face. But maybe you can try a little mental exercise: Ask yourself, "What if?"

What if you simply stop praying when you don't want to? What if you refuse to marry? What are the actual consequences? Sometimes we feel like the world will end if we break the rules, but often, the consequences are bearable.
The world is huge, Lamine. Nothing can easily narrow your entire future down to just "working one job until you die."

Please don't let this internal conflict consume you. I will always support you in chasing the life you actually want.

Take care,
Domino

content:
Dear Domino,

The layoff still feels strange. Not painful, justâ€¦ hollow, it's been 2 weeks already, and it felt like yesterday, like someone suddenly turned off all the background noise I got used to living with. Itâ€™s a weird feeling â€” the body is relieved, but the mind doesnâ€™t know what to do with the silence. One moment, I was caught in the routine, even though it was draining me day by day, and the next moment, everything went still. And in that stillness, I realized how close I was to burning out completely without even noticing.

Thinking about it more, maybe youâ€™re right â€” maybe this wasnâ€™t a setback but a forced stop before something inside me broke down. And with university coming in around three months, the timing lines up in a way that feels almost intentional. Like life pushed everything out of my hands so I could breathe for a moment before the next chapter begins.

When I look back at this year, the burnout makes sense. Working full-time completely destroyed my rhythm. I got home late every night, too tired to think, too tired to do anything I cared about. My sleep got ruined, my days felt compressed, and all the hobbies and routines that used to make me feel like myself slowly faded away. Itâ€™s strange how you donâ€™t notice the damage until you finally step away from the noise.

So I decided that when I go to university, Iâ€™ll only work part-time. Enough to keep me going, but not enough to consume me again. I want to actually live through my uni years. Build better habits. Have time for the things I love. Grow in ways I couldnâ€™t while being tied to a full-time schedule. It feels like choosing myself instead of choosing survival mode. I donâ€™t know exactly how itâ€™ll turn out, but it feels like the right direction â€” and for once, that gives me hope.

Your weekend sounded familiar in a way that made me smile a little â€” that mix of joy and exhaustion. Itâ€™s the kind of thing where the moment itself is good, but the energy cost hits you afterward like a wave. And the car situationâ€¦ yeah. Big responsibilities drain you twice: once with the time they take, and again with the money they demand. Especially when your energy is already stretched thin.

What you said about your health really stuck with me. The headaches, the stomach pain, that heavy fatigue â€” it reads like your body rejecting the environment, not just some flu. That â€œoffice-job syndromeâ€ is real in a way most people underestimate. You can sit in that routine for a long time, convincing yourself itâ€™s normal, but the body always knows when something is wrong. Maybe it isnâ€™t that youâ€™re not built for structure. Maybe youâ€™re just built for a freer kind of life, one where the rhythm is your own, not imposed by fluorescent lights and endless tasks.

Iâ€™ve been dealing with my own kind of heaviness â€” not something sleep fixes, but a quiet weight that sits in the chest and doesnâ€™t move. Since the layoff, some days feel peaceful, like Iâ€™m finally breathing again. Others feel directionless, like Iâ€™m floating without knowing where to land. But Iâ€™m starting to see that this is what transition feels like. Awkward, uncertain, uncomfortable â€” but also full of possibility if you give it time.

Hearing your story made everything feel less lonely. Itâ€™s strange how talking to someone going through their own shift makes your own shift feel more understandable. Like weâ€™re both standing at the edge of the same threshold, trying to figure out the next step.

I donâ€™t know what the next months will bring for either of us, but I hope your health starts to settle. And if your body is telling you that you canâ€™t keep pushing in that office until the end of the year, I really hope you listen to it. Sometimes the body sees the truth long before the mind catches up.

Despite everything, I feelâ€¦ hopeful. Not loudly hopeful, but quietly. The kind that grows slowly, the kind that comes from realizing that change isnâ€™t always a loss â€” sometimes itâ€™s just the start of something better, even if it begins with a tired heart.

Take it easy on yourself, Domi.
Until next time, friend.

Moni

Iâ€™ve always felt more like myself when things are freer and less structured.

Dear Moni,

I could really feel what you were describing in your last letter â€” that strange stillness that comes after everything suddenly stops. Itâ€™s never easy to deal with, but I think youâ€™re handling it with a kind of calm most people donâ€™t have.

About layoffs â€” I understand that feeling all too well. My first official job after graduation ended the day before my three-month mark. The company was downsizing, and since I hadnâ€™t passed my probation yet, I was the easiest one to let go â€” no compensation, just a list of terrible excuses from HR. There wasnâ€™t much I could do, so I accepted it and moved on. A few weeks later, I found another job that I ended up staying in for more than two years (and left on my own terms). So Iâ€™ve come to believe that being laid off isnâ€™t really a disaster â€” itâ€™s just a forced redirection, and sometimes the next stop turns out to be much better.

I was trying to picture your current situation â€” are you already graduated and working full-time, or are you still studying while working on the side? Or maybe preparing for university? I realize I donâ€™t know much about how things work in Egypt. In China, students usually finish high school around 18 and then take the national university entrance exam, the gaokao. Their scores decide which university they can enter, which makes that year one of the most stressful parts of life.

Earlier this year, I took a short gap myself â€” just a few months â€” and I think that was when I really understood what â€œfreedomâ€ feels like. Ever since then, I havenâ€™t been able to fully settle back into an office rhythm again. So I mean it when I say that taking a break isnâ€™t â€œfalling behind.â€ As long as you know itâ€™s rest, not retreat, youâ€™re doing fine.

As for me, Nanjingâ€™s weather has cooled down quite a bit. My cold keeps coming and going â€” Iâ€™m not sure if I never really got over it, or if I keep catching new ones. The office isnâ€™t air-conditioned anymore, but the insulation is awful, so the chill just seeps in. Sometimes I wonder if the right fix is adding one more layer of clothing, or justâ€¦ finding a way out of that office entirely.

I really appreciate you writing so openly about everything. I hope your break gives you clarity and that when you start looking again, youâ€™ll choose something that truly deserves your time. Iâ€™m here â€” and Iâ€™d like to keep hearing about what you discover next, take your pace.

Take care of yourself, and give yourself credit for handling things as calmly as you do.

While Iâ€™ve been forced to learn a lot of survival skills to deal with people who arenâ€™t straightforward, I still resist that style of communication. Itâ€™s like one of my partners once said â€” between friends, simplicity and sincerity work, but when dealing with someone who doesnâ€™t play fair, sticking to a moral baseline can end up putting us at a disadvantage. I still donâ€™t fully agree with that theory, but I wonder if Iâ€™ll feel differently once Iâ€™m the sole person responsible for my own project in the future. ğŸ¤”

Iâ€™m really glad to hear that you consider me one of the true friends youâ€™ve met slowly along the way. I feel the same. Thereâ€™s a certain threshold in letter exchanges, and some friendships disappearing is almost inevitable. But when the quantity of letters exchanged reaches a certain point, thatâ€™s when a qualitative shift happens. Regardless, Iâ€™m truly happy to have met you and to have these deeper conversations with you.

Today, I donâ€™t know why, but I came down with a pretty bad cold (maybe I kicked off the blanket last night). Iâ€™ve been feeling weak all day and struggling to concentrate. I took some over-the-counter medicine and hope to recover quickly.

Take care of yourself too. Looking forward to hearing from you again.

Dear Domino,

Reading your letter truly made me smile. I can imagine how overwhelming it must be to juggle three projects at once, and Iâ€™m glad youâ€™re thinking about letting go of the smaller, low-priority ones. Sometimes itâ€™s easy to forget that protecting your own time and energy is just as important as meeting deadlines. Iâ€™ve been noticing the same on my end â€” handling projects outside of our usual niche has been a challenge, but itâ€™s also a chance to grow and learn new ways of working. Thereâ€™s a strange satisfaction in navigating uncertainty, even if it means constantly adjusting and figuring out what works. Itâ€™s like walking through a forest youâ€™ve never been in before â€” intimidating at first, but exciting once you start noticing the paths.

The three pictures you sent of the road that leads up to Purple Mountain are absolutely stunning. That is pure autumn energy! I honestly thought New York had the best autumn vibe, but your photos and your description have me reconsidering. The golden canopy, the soft sunlight filtering through the branches, and the calm feeling that comes with the crisp air â€” itâ€™s magical. Knowing the history behind those trees makes it feel even more alive, almost like they carry stories from a century ago. I could almost hear the leaves rustling and smell the faint earthy scent after rain. Pure magic.

Autumn here in Maadi is a little underwhelming in comparison, haha. The trees donâ€™t really turn yellow or orange; only the very tops show hints of change. Days are still warm, though the evenings carry a slight coolness, which is nice. Even with that, I still prefer winter here â€” thereâ€™s something peaceful about the contrast of cooler nights and warmer days. The sunlight is softer too, casting a different kind of golden glow over the streets and buildings. Itâ€™s subtle, but in its own way, it makes the city feel calm and reflective, and I try to notice those little moments when I can.

Itâ€™s already been 10 days since I started my break from everything besides work, but Iâ€™m planning for my comeback to all my activities. I want to get back into the gym, my side projects, and all the little routines that make my days feel full. Itâ€™s motivating to think about diving back in, and having had this small pause makes me feel ready to approach everything with a fresher perspective. Iâ€™ve been catching up on movies, shows, and games in the meantime â€” I just finished the first season of The Walking Dead, and it really hit me like a dashing train. The episodic format across seasons one through three makes every decision feel weighty, and I love how the story unfolds based on the choices you make. Iâ€™d genuinely recommend it if you like games that let your actions shape the narrative.

Oh, and a silly little note â€” my hair has finally reached medium length, so I started tying it up while working. I truly want to grow it even further, but managing it and getting enough sleep has been such a battle. Iâ€™m fighting the urge to just go for a clean buzz cut, so tying it up is my little sanity-saving compromise for now.

I feel like Iâ€™m slowly learning how to give myself permission to take things at my own pace, which has been comforting. Life can be so busy and chaotic that itâ€™s easy to forget how good it feels to just slow down and enjoy the little things â€” even if itâ€™s a quiet afternoon, a walk outside, or a small ritual like catching a game or reading a story. Iâ€™m trying to appreciate these moments while I can.

Take care of yourself too, Domino. Donâ€™t let the projects steal your calm â€” you deserve that quiet golden tunnel of leaves, even if only in your mind for a moment. I hope youâ€™re finding space to breathe and enjoy small moments for yourself, just like the autumn streets you captured in those photos.

Warmly,
Moni

That said, thereâ€™s one thing I absolutely canâ€™t stand â€” wasabi. I have a bit of PTSD from it, honestly. When I was a kid, during my first-ever Japanese meal, one of my relatives told me that wasabi was sweetâ€¦ and of course, I believed them. So I took a huge scoop of it, straight into my mouth â€” no hesitation. You can probably imagine what happened next. Ever since that traumatic day, wasabi and I have had an irreparable relationship.

As for road trips â€” my favorite ones didnâ€™t actually start from Nanjing, but from Northeast China in a city called Shenyang. I spent almost all of last year living there because my boyfriend was based up north. I actually drove all the way from Nanjing to meet him â€” yes, it was a â€œmeeting-the-boyfriend-in-real-lifeâ€ kind of journey â€” and this year, we both moved back to Nanjing together.

While I was living there, I drove around a lot. Sometimes Iâ€™d head south to Dalian, a coastal city that used to be one of Chinaâ€™s most important ports â€” kind of like Hong Kong in its early days. It still has fascinating old international-style buildings, and the seafood there is incredible. I love seafood so much that Iâ€™d sometimes drive six or seven hours in a single day just to have a perfect meal.

Other times, Iâ€™d go north toward Inner Mongolia, where the salty milk tea and beef are unforgettable. My time in Shenyang was actually really happy. I had just bought my car, so that sense of freedom felt brand new and intoxicating. Sometimes my boyfriend and I would sit in the car debating what to eat for dinner â€” and half an hour later, weâ€™d find ourselves three hundred kilometers away, eating seafood or grilled beef. That, to me, felt like the ideal kind of lifeâ€¦ just a little expensive, haha.

And congrats again on your ping-pong victory! ğŸ“ğŸ‰ I bet that victory meal tasted even better than usual.

It makes me really happy to hear how passionate you are about China. Honestly, itâ€™s a country thatâ€™s definitely worth experiencing. If you ever do come here, you have to let me know. Iâ€™ll make sure to take you out for some amazing food â€” thatâ€™s a promise. ğŸ˜„

Dear Moni,

Workâ€™s been a bit overwhelming lately â€” I somehow ended up juggling three different projects at once. Itâ€™s been tricky trying to give each of them the attention they deserve without burning myself out. Iâ€™ve started thinking about letting go of a few smaller, low-paying tasks just to breathe again. Sometimes, earning a little less feels like a fair trade for staying sane. I guess Iâ€™m slowly learning that â€œbusyâ€ doesnâ€™t always mean â€œproductive.â€

Meanwhile, autumn has really settled into Nanjing. The temperature drops fast here once the season changes â€” nights are already around 10Â°C, and the air has that clean, crisp bite that makes you want to walk slower. I think autumn is the most beautiful time of year in this city. Youâ€™d probably like it â€” the streets are lined with towering rows of French sycamores, what we call æ³•å›½æ¢§æ¡.

Thereâ€™s a bit of a romantic story behind them. Back in the early 20th century, when Nanjing served as the capital of the Republic of China, the leader at the time â€” Sun Yat-sen â€” wanted to make the city greener and more pleasant. His wife, Soong Ching-ling, loved sycamores, so he ordered them to be planted along the main avenues. The trees thrived, and now, nearly a century later, theyâ€™ve grown into huge canopies that stretch across both sides of the roads, their branches meeting overhead like a vaulted ceiling of gold every autumn.

One of the most famous spots is the road that leads up Purple Mountain. In October and November, it turns into a glowing tunnel of yellow leaves, especially when the sun filters through the branches in the late afternoon. I filmed a short project there a few years ago â€” I couldnâ€™t find the footage anymore, but I still remember the sound of the leaves rustling and the faint smell of the earth after rain. Itâ€™s one of those places that makes you feel calm without trying.

Whatâ€™s autumn like in Egypt? Or does the weather stay warm for most of the year? I imagine the light must look beautiful in a different way â€” softer maybe, more golden against the desert tones. Iâ€™ve always wondered how the seasons feel there, since I only know Egypt through pictures and stories.

Anyway, I hope youâ€™re feeling better and taking care of yourself. I know youâ€™ve had a rough stretch lately, so please donâ€™t rush to return to your full rhythm right away.

Take care,
Domino

I mean, I love sushi, but would I drive that far for it? ...Okay, maybe I would ğŸ˜… The struggle is real! At least you have that small Japanese restaurant in Nanjing with amazing foie gras sushi â€” that sounds like a hidden gem! Thanks for sharing the photos, by the way. Now I'm even more motivated to ace my midterms so I can justify my sushi reward ğŸ£

I can totally understand why the office "glass box" life feels uncomfortable. You seem like someone who thrives with **freedom and flexibility** rather than rigid structures. Life's too short to feel trapped in something that doesn't bring you joy, right?

I'm kind of in between, I think. I can adapt to different environments â€” whether it's structure or freedom, I can roll with it. But deep down, I also value having the space to breathe and do things my own way. So yeah, I get where you're coming from!

So yeah, still very much pursuing that dream!

Do you have a favorite nearby city you've driven to? Or a memorable road trip moment?

I do get out and explore when I can, though â€” whether it's hopping on a motorbike or just wandering around. And hey, **speaking of unwinding** â€” last weekend I played ping pong with my friends and I actually WON! ğŸ“ğŸ‰ Which means they had to treat me to food afterward. Best. Feeling. Ever. There's nothing quite like victory snacks, haha.

Anyway, I hope your week is going well! Enjoy those road trips, keep hunting for good sushi, and maybe one day we can compare notes on the best sushi spots in China vs Indonesia ğŸ˜„

Oh, and to answer your question: my go-to sushi order is basically **anything with unagi** and a side of salmon sashimi. What about you â€” besides foie gras and sashimi, do you have any other must-orders?

Looking forward to your next letter!

Sometimes, when weâ€™re used to pushing through things, itâ€™s hard to tell when our body is genuinely asking us to stop. I tend to think a lot (sometimes too much), especially when it comes to health or uncertain things. But youâ€™re right â€” once youâ€™ve done your part, the rest isnâ€™t really in your control. I think Iâ€™m starting to see the beauty in letting things be for once.

Actually, this whole health issue started while I was training at the gym. I was in the middle of a set when suddenly my head started spinning â€” the kind of dizziness that makes you feel like the room itself is rotating. When I stood up from the machine, it honestly felt like everything tilted to the left, and for a second, I thought I might be having a stroke. I remember saying â€œfuckâ€ under my breath and trying to walk it off, but my lower body started burning, my abs tightened up uncontrollably, and I felt waves of nausea. I somehow made it to the changing room and just sat there for a while, shaking, trying to make sense of what was happening. It was one of the scariest moments Iâ€™ve had in a long time.

A good fellow there noticed me sitting like a zombie and came over to check on me. I told him what I was feeling, and it turned out he was a doctor. He quickly diagnosed it as a vasovagal reaction, explaining that I probably just overexerted myself and needed to sit tight and hydrate. He was kind enough to give me a ride home afterward â€” I was so out of it I didnâ€™t even catch his name. When I got home, I oddly felt like taking a cold shower (which I never do; I usually prefer warm ones). After that, I booked a doctorâ€™s appointment and took the day off work. Thankfully, everything checked out fine â€” it really was just exhaustion from pushing myself too hard. Iâ€™ve been taking it slow since then.

My break has been surprisingly peaceful since. Iâ€™m not used to having this much free time, but it feels refreshing. Iâ€™ve been spending it catching up on a few movies and games I left halfway, and honestly, it feels nice doing things just because I want to, without any rush or structure. I actually just finished the first season of The Walking Dead â€” that game hit me like a speeding train. I didnâ€™t expect it to be that emotional or immersive. If you like games where your actions and decisions shape the story, I really recommend giving it a try. Itâ€™s one of those experiences that stays with you long after you finish it.

I liked what you said about maybe being better suited to a flexible, independent life. That actually resonates with me a lot â€” I think Iâ€™m built the same way. Thereâ€™s something freeing about not being tied to strict routines or having to fit into a certain rhythm. Maybe thatâ€™s why I admire how youâ€™ve shaped your own path. It feels like youâ€™ve found a balance between structure and freedom, which is something Iâ€™m still working on.

Good luck with your HAM exam preparations â€” I can tell how much passion youâ€™ve poured into it. Iâ€™m sure when the time comes, youâ€™ll pass it easily. Iâ€™m looking forward to hearing how your first transmission goes â€” I feel like itâ€™ll be a special moment for you.

Take care, Domino, and thank you again for the thoughtful words. I really do appreciate the way you see things â€” it always leaves me reflecting a bit deeper.

Looking forward to your next letter, friend,
Moni

Wow, marriage planning sounds both exciting and overwhelming! I totally get why you'd want to tie it to your boyfriend's Portsmouth memoriesâ€”that "return-to-the-past" honeymoon concept is so romantic. About the "glass box" office lifeâ€”I feel you on that one, even though I haven't fully entered the working world yet. Seven or eight hours in one place does sound suffocating. Dear Moni,

I kept forgetting to log in these past two days â€” finally remembered to reply today, so apologies for the delay.

About Red Dead Redemption â€” Iâ€™ve only played the second one. After spending so much time in RDR2, it feels strange to go back to the first game, even the remastered version. The controls just donâ€™t feel the same, so I never stuck with it. But RDR2? Iâ€™ve finished the story more than once. Rockstar really put so much care into it â€” the world-building, the writing, the attention to detail. Theyâ€™re a company with real ambition. Iâ€™ve also enjoyed the GTA series for the same reason: their stories are always layered, sometimes absurd, but strangely human too. If you havenâ€™t played RDR2 yet, you absolutely should â€” itâ€™s an experience worth having.

When it comes to games, my interests usually split in two directions: stunning visuals (like the Forza Horizon racing series) and captivating stories. If the narrative is strong enough, I donâ€™t mind if the graphics arenâ€™t perfect. Disco Elysium is a good example â€” itâ€™s not about photorealism, but the art style and writing draw you in completely.

Speaking of stories, I rewatched The Martian yesterday. Iâ€™ve always had a soft spot for hard sci-fi â€” the kind that feels grounded in real science but still leaves you wide-eyed. In China, thereâ€™s actually a novella with a very similar premise called Dead on Mars. The ending isnâ€™t perfect, but I loved the setup. And of course, Liu Cixinâ€™s Three-Body Problem â€” maybe youâ€™ve heard of it? That one is on a whole different scale.

On the real-life front: Iâ€™ve scheduled my motorcycle test again â€” itâ€™s in two days. Tomorrow Iâ€™m planning to visit the test center, walk the grounds, maybe even pay for a short practice run if they allow it. Hopefully this time Iâ€™ll have better luck.

And one more thing: the first week of October is our National Day holiday here. Iâ€™m planning to take a high-speed train (not driving this time) to the city where my mom lives, to spend some time with her and my relatives. Itâ€™ll be good to reconnect â€” itâ€™s been a while.

Until next time,
Domino

Like you, Iâ€™d rather build something sustainable and tangible than gamble on something I donâ€™t fully grasp. Still, the technical side is fascinating â€” decentralized systems, devices acting together, new ways to store and share information â€” those ideas feel like seeds of something meaningful in the long run.

Those little purchases always feel rewarding, even if they werenâ€™t strictly necessary.

Moments like the one you described â€” enjoying good food, laughing with loved ones â€” feel like investments in memory, not money. In the end, I think those are the things that stay with us longer than anything stored away in numbers.

Lately Iâ€™ve been keeping my shopping habits more balanced. I mostly spend on gadgets like a new smartwatch, headphones, or laptop accessories, and from time to time I treat myself with some self-care products or gym clothes.

But more than that, sharing it with my family made the night unforgettableâ€”we walked out of the theater quietly at first, each of us still lost in thought, and then slowly the conversation grew, everyone reflecting in their own way. Itâ€™s one of those memories that I think will stay with me for a long time.

content:
Hi Lamine ğŸ˜Ÿ

About freelancing â€” my answer is: yes, itâ€™s hard. I often feel anxious, sometimes even short-tempered. I know my state of mind isnâ€™t always right, but for now I donâ€™t have a real solution. Iâ€™m simply not the kind of person who can accept â€œstability.â€ In China, many people dream of civil service jobs, but I never consider that path. The idea of working in the same position for decades until retirement feels like a personal disaster. Even if it means stress and uncertainty, Iâ€™d rather live a short life that touches as many new things as possible.

You mentioned not wanting to visit Arab countries â€” honestly, I partly agree. For me, what influences me more is the attitude toward Muslims. I feel that some parts of Islamic doctrine are strange and outdated. I donâ€™t think itâ€™s a great religion (but then again, is there any â€œperfectâ€ religion in this world? Except maybe the Flying Spaghetti Monster ğŸ˜…).

About racism â€” I think your point about â€œignoranceâ€ is probably right. Especially with discrimination against Asians, a lot of it comes from old stereotypes and, as you said, lack of understanding. To me, what really divides people is education and environment (both geographic and social). Green Book is my favorite road movie, without question. It dives deep into the issue of racism while also telling a powerful human story. I loved it.

Regarding the rise of extreme voices online â€” I have a theory. In the past, the internet had higher entry barriers. Owning a PC and being able to access information communities required a certain level of education and resources, which shaped a healthier online environment. Later, with Web 2.0, the internet expanded to almost everyone. Thereâ€™s a Chinese saying: â€œWhen the forest grows, all kinds of birds appear.â€ Thatâ€™s exactly how I see todayâ€™s internet. Many people with limited perspectives or difficult lives use the internet to vent their frustrations. Maybe in real life they receive no respect, so the only way they can assert themselves is by attacking strangers online.

Tomorrow Iâ€™ll fly to Hong Kong for a work trip that lasts about a week. My motorcycle exam will have to wait until I get back. I do enjoy driving, though. Still, I think most people I know in China see driving as just a necessary skill, not something to enjoy. My boyfriend, for example, has a license but rarely drives our car â€” he prefers just calling a taxi.

But Yoshiâ€¦ oh my god. I was shocked and furious to read what happened. How could someone hurt an innocent cat like that? It makes me both angry and deeply sad. When I saw the photo, my chest tightened â€” poor Yoshi, I can only imagine how scared and hurt he must have been. If I were there, I literally would have cried and wanted to punch someone. I truly hope he recovers well, and that you too can find a little peace. I know how exhausting anxiety and insomnia can be, and this kind of event makes it so much worse. As for your brother and sister-in-law, I believe there must be reasons behind such a painful choice. Adults sometimes have to make hard decisionsâ€¦ but I still hope things will settle in the best possible way for them, and for you.

Please give Yoshi a gentle pat from me.

Take care,
Domino ğŸŒ¿

Dear Moni,

About Web3 â€” if Iâ€™m being honest, my advice to most people is to just keep it at the â€œcuriosityâ€ level. The current environment is still far from healthy. Itâ€™s mostly a mix of chaos, whales squeezing smaller players, and gamblers chasing the next big hit. Maybe this is what a completely free version of the stock market would look like. Personally, Iâ€™ve always felt finance isnâ€™t the kind of field I want to stake my future on. Iâ€™m not good at speculation, and I hold onto the belief that â€œyou canâ€™t earn money beyond the limits of your own understanding.â€ So instead of trying to outsmart the markets, Iâ€™d rather stick to the â€œdumb wayâ€ â€” selling my time and labor, bit by bit, to build something sustainable. It may not be glamorous, but at least it feels like a path I can control.

That being said, I still find Web3 interesting in a more technical sense. The idea of decentralized systems, peopleâ€™s devices working together as a â€œserver,â€ and new ways of publishing or storing content â€” thatâ€™s something worth paying attention to. Even if itâ€™s messy now, the principles might spark better use cases in the future. For me, playing with it is less about chasing money and more about trying to understand where things might be headed.

On a lighter note â€” I went out last night with my boyfriend and my roommate to Hamazushi. I donâ€™t know if youâ€™ve heard of it, but itâ€™s a conveyor-belt sushi chain here. I wouldnâ€™t say Iâ€™m poor, but letâ€™s just say my Engel coefficient (the share of income spent on food) stays embarrassingly high. Food is one of those things I canâ€™t seem to compromise on. Some people save for fashion or gadgets; I end up saving for dinner.

Moments like that remind me of how I live â€” not chasing speculation, not hoarding wealth, but spending where it actually brings joy. Maybe thatâ€™s its own kind of investment, even if it doesnâ€™t grow in numbers. What about you? Do you have that one food or indulgence that always ruins your budget but still feels worth it every single time?

Take care,

Instead, lots of devices around the world share the role of being â€œthe server.â€ Imagine it as a kind of United States in cyberspace â€” but without a federal government. Each device saves part of the data and contributes to the computations, and together they keep the content available to users. Thatâ€™s why people call it a â€œchain.â€

I only started digging deeper into it recently. The reason was that a developer on a geeky forum I often visit made a couple of projects that caught my interest. One was a decentralized blogging system where my posts arenâ€™t stored on his server, but on the devices of other users who run the program. My blog stays online as long as this â€œchain of PCsâ€ is alive, and every time someone visits, it connects through the network. The second project was that the forum owner even launched his own cryptocurrency, named after the forum itself. I bought a little, not as an investment, but just to understand how things actually work in practice.

By the way, you said youâ€™ve started learning French! I studied it back in university, though I didnâ€™t invest much effort at the time. Compared to driving a manual car, I feel like motorcycles are quicker to get the hang of (though maybe thatâ€™s just because Iâ€™ve already had years of driving experience). Iâ€™ve only done 1.5 practice sessions so far, but Iâ€™m feeling confident. My test is the day after tomorrow â€” fingers crossed I can pass it in one go!

Dear Domino,

Your message made me smile â€” it felt like a cozy fireside chat, complete with owls and windswept beaches.

I totally get the Hedwig effect! That snowy fluffball made owls iconic for an entire generation. And Yoll â€” I haven't seen any content for it before, but when I did that owl too, with those impossibly expressive eyes. Itâ€™s funny how animals can feel so familiar even when we only meet them through screens. I wish the pet laws were more flexible where you are â€” I imagine an owl perched quietly nearby would suit you quite well.

You nailed it with the Instax Mini Evo. It is indeed an instant camera, and I love the idea of capturing moments without fussing over settings. But your point about creative limitations is spot-on. Iâ€™ve been leaning toward something that lets me capture the moment with that dreamy Polaroid effect, so maybe an instant camera is enough for me. Thanks for the nudge â€” I needed that.

And wow â€” I didnâ€™t realize that was you in the photo! You pulled off the solo beach shoot like a pro. I can picture you trudging through the sand with all that gear, determined to get the shot. That kind of effort says a lot about your passion â€” and your stamina.

I donâ€™t think youâ€™re cold at all. Life moves, and not everyone stays in our orbit. Iâ€™ve lost touch with all of my childhood friends too except for my best friend hes doing well now he went to the united states and is entering uni soon to study aero space enginerring im so proud of him hes the only person from my past who liked me for who i am and Iâ€™ve come to see it as natural. Some people are meant to be chapters, not constants. Still, I admire your friends pursuing PhDs â€” that kind of dedication is rare,
I have a story related to this topic. A former contact of mine (bully) reached out to me in my DMs. He just sent me my name, and I didn't recognize him until he introduced himself. I felt annoyed inside but brushed it off and greeted him warmly, as if he were an old friend reaching back. I played along, but each message he sent was an insult in disguise. I was patient for three or four messages until I asked why he was reaching out all of a sudden. Of course, he got defensive, claiming we were old friends and he just wanted to reconnect. I recognized his toneâ€”similar to years agoâ€”and knew he was trying to play mind games, which I refused to give him the satisfaction of. I stayed calm but stood my ground, telling him directly that I remembered how he treated me before and that his words didn't show genuine intent to reconnect. He went quiet for a while, then tried to dismiss it with a laugh, implying I was overreacting. This guy made my life hell when I was in high school back in my home country. I didn't take the bait and left him on read, going silent. It wasn't the best move on my part, but I drew the line. He kept messaging me for two days, asking for a chance to explain, and I said, Okay, nowâ€™s your chance. We then had a surprisingly sincere conversation. It was just his usual rude writing style. I should have kept my composure more; I listened to what he had to say. He didn't apologize for the past, but that was okay. He seemed to be trying to become a better person, which felt like closure for me. He said he was reaching out to his old contacts for mutual benefits, which I didn't expect, but I agreed if that was his view. We parted ways peacefully, although it felt like finishing unfinished business from the past.

Itâ€™s reassuring to hear you speak so kindly about your own journey. Even if the last few years werenâ€™t perfect, it sounds like youâ€™ve built a solid foundation. And thank you for your words about love â€” they genuinely comforted me. Iâ€™m learning to trust my own timing, even if it doesnâ€™t match the worldâ€™s pace.

The university Iâ€™m aiming for is in France, but realistically, I will attend Alexandria University for now until I prepare all the documents and a plan. Once Iâ€™m ready, I will transfer to France as an exchange student, and there is a way I can get a job when I arrive. It feels surreal â€” like standing at the edge of something vast and unknown. But I hear you asking why France specifically. Well, itâ€™s one of the easiest European countries to obtain their citizenship. Iâ€™m not interested in citizenship itself, but rather the passport, which allows visa-free travel to 194 countries, almost all the countries in the world, making the odyssey far more feasible. Also, wages in France are high, so working there alongside my studies could help me save a considerable amount of money for the journey. French universities are very affordableâ€”around 180 euros per semester. I imagine starting the odyssey romantically after finishing university, but realistically, perhaps in my late 20s. It still has some romance, but I donâ€™t want to do it as an old man! Thatâ€™s my current plan, but if you have any ideas to improve it, let me know. If you come up with a good idea, Iâ€™d love to add it to the plan.

Canâ€™t wait to hear more from you â€” your letters always feel like a breath of fresh air.

Your friend,
Moni

Dear Domino,
Reading your letter felt like opening a window into your worldâ€”quietly vivid, layered with experience, and full of thoughtfulness. I appreciate how much you shared, and I have to say, Iâ€™m still left wanting to know more. Youâ€™ve lived through so many shifts, and yet thereâ€™s a calm clarity in how you speak about it all. Itâ€™s rare.

Your comment about Debbieâ€™s â€œsuccessorâ€ made me smile, even if it was a bit cruel. I understandâ€”cats are complicated, and having two at once can feel like inviting chaos into the house. Having just one cat seems like a sensible choice. Seeing Debbieâ€™s photo was cute, almost like catching a glimpse of your worldâ€”thereâ€™s something grounding about seeing the animals that influence our daily lives. I'm thinking about getting an owl someday because I find them poetically resonant. In Arabic, being called an owl means youâ€™re acting too much like an introvert, and your posture resembles the nervous stand you do when youâ€™re anxious. I was often called out for that while growing up.

Your trip to the sea clearly left a mark, and Iâ€™m glad my words resonated with that. Thereâ€™s something timeless about the ocean, isnâ€™t there? It doesnâ€™t just reflect our moodsâ€”it absorbs them. I hope your travel list keeps growing, and that each destination brings not just stories, but new versions of yourself.
And the view of the trip was beautiful, skyscrapers in the background of the sea. I really need to get some pointers from you, my guy. I was never into photography, but now I want to make it one of my hobbies. I'm thinking of getting the Instax Mini Evo, it offers both the aesthetics and functionality I'm chasing as a beginner. If you have recommendations for beginner cameras, enlighten me right away. Also, was that blonde guy your boyfriend or yours?

Your filmmaking journey is fascinating. That middle-school documentary crew sounds like a beautiful messâ€”chaotic, yes, but also formative. Itâ€™s strange how the things we create early on, even if they vanish, still shape us. Losing those videos mustâ€™ve been tough, but I admire how youâ€™ve reframed it. Maybe it really was life nudging you forward, reminding you not to get stuck in nostalgia. Even though I'm guilty myself, I tend to daydream about my childhood friends and what happened to them now. 

Your path through high school and university feels familiar in its unpredictability. That tension between wanting to break free and choosing to stay the courseâ€”itâ€™s something I think many of us wrestle with. I respect your decision to pursue French broadcasting and how you found ways to stay close to the media even when the system didnâ€™t fully align with your spirit. Freelancing through an ad agency, working with car brands, growing from editing to shootingâ€”itâ€™s clear youâ€™ve built your skills with intention. And now, living off freelance projects, even if itâ€™s not your ideal, shows a kind of quiet resilience.
I really appreciated your advice about university. Iâ€™m about to step into that world, and your words felt like a compass. â€œLet your choices be yours aloneâ€â€”that hit deep. Itâ€™s easy to get swept up in what looks prestigious or important, especially when everyoneâ€™s chasing something. Iâ€™ll keep your warning about student unions in mind. I donâ€™t know how things will unfold here, but Iâ€™ll try to stay true to what feels real and meaningful.

Your description of campus life was beautiful. It reminded me that university isnâ€™t just about academicsâ€”itâ€™s about becoming. Trying, failing, connecting, disconnecting, falling in love, starting things, letting go. Iâ€™ll carry that with me.

As for your relationship, I hear you. Being apart now and then is one thing, but noticing patterns that donâ€™t sit rightâ€”thatâ€™s something else. I hope you find the clarity you need, whether through conversation or reflection. Relationships are rarely simple, and it takes courage to face the parts that feel off.
I'm speaking like someone who knows what they're saying, but I've never had a romantic relationship before. How ironic, I hear you say, haha

Thank you again for writing with such openness. I feel like Iâ€™ve gotten more glimpses of your world, but Iâ€™d love to know moreâ€”what you dream about, what keeps you up at night, what youâ€™re still searching for. Iâ€™ll be here, listening. If you also want to have a glimpse of my world, ask right  away, a good conversation goes both ways

Until next time, friend,
Moni

Dear Moni,

About Debbieâ€™s â€œsuccessorâ€ â€” I think thatâ€™ll only happen after his time is up. Sounds a bit cruel, I know, but Iâ€™m not really a fan of raising two cats at once. I always imagine theyâ€™d fight, so for now itâ€™s one cat at a time.

Thank you for resonating with my trip to the sea. My travel list is still very, very long, and Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™ll find ways to reach more places in the future. Hopefully with more good stories involved.

Since you asked, hereâ€™s the rough path of my career:
Back in middle school, I first found my love for filmmaking. I used to play around with miniDVs and CCD cameras, shooting little vlog-style videos, and even roped in my classmates to make a short â€œdocumentaryâ€ about my hometown. (Middle-school film crewâ€¦ it was more chaos than cinema.) Side note â€” all of those videos vanished in a NAS disaster years later. No backups, nothing. Maybe it was lifeâ€™s way of telling me not to stare too long into the rearview mirror. Anyway, from that time on, I felt certain Iâ€™d make filmmaking my profession.

High school wasnâ€™t easy â€” I disliked studying and almost dropped out to start a business. In the end, I chose to go to university, majoring in French broadcasting, which at least kept me tied to media. During my first two years, I began freelancing in video post-production, mostly through an ad agency that worked with car companies like Honda. By senior year, during my internship, I finally got my hands on professional cameras, and my skills grew from pure editing into both shooting and cutting.

After several jobs, my work expanded to include social media operations, which pulled me deeper into marketing. By now Iâ€™ve stepped away from office life, but the skills Iâ€™ve gathered allow me to live off freelance projects â€” shooting, editing, and running campaigns. Itâ€™s sustainable, but not my ideal. I suspect Iâ€™ll eventually choose to start my own thing.

Now, back to university â€” first of all, congratulations on becoming a student soon ğŸ‰! From my experience, the one thing thatâ€™s non-negotiable is: let your choices be yours alone. I donâ€™t know how it works on your side of the Indian Ocean, but in China, student unions areâ€¦ honestly, not worth the time. They sell themselves as growth and responsibility, but mostly itâ€™s just volunteering for the school while chasing a vague sense of prestige. What is worth it: university life itself. For many, itâ€™s the first time living away from family for years, which makes it the perfect place to test and grow self-discipline, independence, and social skills.

The campus can embrace nearly anything: study whatever excites you, meet whoever you want, try things that might look a little crazy, fall in love, navigate relationships, start a project (or fail one). These are things you may never get the chance to do again before or after those years. Donâ€™t waste them on someone elseâ€™s agenda.

As for me, life is mostly steady, though my boyfriend and I are apart now and then. That partâ€™s fine, but lately Iâ€™ve been thinking about some of his patterns â€” he can be a little too childish sometimes. Iâ€™m debating whether itâ€™s time to sit down and talk it through.

Oh, and I finally got approval to send photos. I can only attach four per letter, so this time Iâ€™m sending a few from my last trip â€” and, of course, one of Debbie.

Until next time,
Domino

Those are the kinds of memories that etch themselves into you, the ones that outlast the pretty, easy ones.

The story of the hillside heart made me smile, though I can see why the climb would be too much for someone with a fear of heights. It feels like one of those strange, beautiful markers we all have tucked away, something we carry forward simply because it has always been there, a quiet testament to love in another time.

I can sense the shift in how you speak about him now â€” not as a perfect mirror to your pace, but as someone whose steps fall differently, yet still in your direction. That takes a certain grace to see and accept. The way you notice his gestures â€” the meals, the care for your home, the small act of making you a nightcap â€” says as much about you as it does about him. Dear Moni,

Iâ€™m finally back home, completely worn out.
This journey took more out of me than I expected. And now Iâ€™m alone here for a while â€” my boyfriend is still up north with his parents. Thankfully, Debbie was waiting at home, so at least Iâ€™m not returning to an empty apartment.

The trip itself didnâ€™t go as planned. Halfway through, my boyfriend had to return to his hometown, which left me to finish the journey on my own(family business). And just as if fate was playing with me, I arrived at the coast right when Typhoon Podul passed over the area.
Heavy rain poured through the night and into the next day, swallowing the whole island on the weather radar. It wasnâ€™t what I had imagined, but maybe thatâ€™s the beauty of it. I drove out to the shoreline and watched the sea in the storm, gray and violent. Later, when the rain finally eased, I walked down to the beach and let the waves hit my legs. It wasnâ€™t cinematic sunlight and blue skies, but it was raw and real. And sometimes thatâ€™s enough.

This was also the first time I brought my bf to my hometown. I even wanted to show him a giant heart my dad once carved into a hillside when he was dating my mom. But the path was too steep, and heâ€™s afraid of heights, so I had to leave him at the foot of the hill â€” it's a strange little family landmark that I showed to lots of my friends.
In the end, the trip wasnâ€™t perfect. But I stood there, I breathed it in, and I came back with pieces of the sea still clinging to me.
By the way, Iâ€™ve already applied on the app to send photos â€” so in my next letter, Iâ€™ll share a few shots from the coast with you.

And about my boyfriend as you mentionedâ€¦ once I used to imagine him as a life partner in the full sense â€” someone whoâ€™d walk in rhythm with me step by step. But Iâ€™ve realized itâ€™s not easy for him to move that way. If I push, it only creates more friction. So lately Iâ€™ve been thinking maybe I should go easier on him. He might not always keep pace with me, but he does love me in his own way â€” cooking, taking care of things at home, even making me a little nightcap when Iâ€™m stressed. Thatâ€™s worth holding on to.

As for my late nights â€” I think I found the culprit. Lately Iâ€™ve become unusually sensitive to caffeine. If I drink anything after noon, my whole night is ruined with restlessness. Which means itâ€™s not that I â€œbelong to the nightâ€â€¦ itâ€™s just bad timing with my coffee cup. Typical me.

For now, Iâ€™m glad to be home, even if Iâ€™m still recovering from the miles. By the time you read this, Iâ€™ll be remembering the stormy sea rather than the sunlight I thought Iâ€™d find â€” and maybe thatâ€™s the kind of memory that lasts longer anyway.

Talk soon,
Domino

Dear Moni,

So â€” I watched Kikiâ€™s Delivery Service.
And wowâ€¦ Miyazaki really has a gift for weaving together beautiful little details into something timeless. Thereâ€™s a kind of beauty in this film that feels removed from time â€” so much so that I never felt like I was watching something made decades ago.
Story-wise, itâ€™s designed to be â€œmistake-proofâ€ â€” in a way thatâ€™s almost textbook. I could see the intention behind each choice, each little beat. But maybe thatâ€™s exactly why itâ€™s a classic â€” because itâ€™s so deliberate without losing warmth.
The art direction, thoughâ€¦ I loved it. Considering the era, itâ€™s incredible how they kept enough frames for smooth motion while still making each shot aesthetically rich.
That little coastal town â€” was it based on somewhere in Italy? The atmosphere felt so vivid, like Iâ€™d seen it in JoJoâ€™s Bizarre Adventure: Golden Wind. The same kind of sunlit streets, sea breeze, and lived-in charm.

What you wrote about my boyfriend â€” I think you summed him up perfectly. And about growing up in a kind environmentâ€¦ hmm. Iâ€™m not sure if itâ€™s purely a good thing or not. Iâ€™m not exactly a scheming, manipulative person myself, but I do believe self-protection is important. Thatâ€™s something I donâ€™t really see in himâ€¦ which I guess means I end up being the one to protect him. (Sigh.)

Iâ€™m glad youâ€™ve fixed your sleep schedule â€” unfortunately, Iâ€™m the opposite right now. My body clock has been slipping into a nocturnal rhythm lately. I know itâ€™s not great, but between the late-night restlessness and the morning struggle to get out of bed, I havenâ€™t found a fix.
That said, tomorrow Iâ€™m waking up early for my southbound road trip â€” maybe this journey will be the reset I need. By the time you read this, I should be about 600 kilometers away from home.

Talk soon â€” hopefully with stories from the road.
Domino

Itâ€™s been such a long time since Iâ€™ve seen real blue skies, white clouds, and clear ocean water. The closest sea to my city (Nanjing) is at the mouth of the Yangtze River, which means the river carries all its mud and silt downstream, turning the nearby sea a muddy yellow (you can even see it on Google Earth!). So, for the past few days, Iâ€™ve been planning this trip â€” driving with my boyfriend all the way to the southern coast of China, not too far from the side facing Taiwan. The water there is supposed to be beautiful. The only problem isâ€¦ the weather forecast for the next few weeks is not great. Iâ€™ve been debating whether I should really drive ten hours just to stand by a dark, cloudy ocean for one afternoon. But in the end, I decided to go anyway. Tomorrow Iâ€™ll pack my bags, fill up the car, and get ready to leave!

And thank you for your kind wishes about our wedding. I can tell you with absolute certainty â€” love between men does exist. Sex and love are not the same thing. Iâ€™ve met many people, had a few relationships, and eventually found stability with my current partner. I believe choosing your other half is a process of filtering and learning. So please, little brother, donâ€™t let one manâ€™s bitter comment kill your desire for love.

About Maliâ€¦ I just looked at some news. Is your country going through a difficult situation right now? I saw that the Chinese embassy even issued an evacuation notice. I donâ€™t know the exact details, but I hope everything is okay on your side. As for what you said about â€œnot being able to leaveâ€ â€” well, I think in life we all have to find the way of living that makes us feel safest and most comfortable. If staying in your own neighborhood gives you that sense of security, thatâ€™s not necessarily a bad thing. (sending you another big hug ğŸ¤—)

And your catâ€¦ oh my god, so cute! I can totally imagine them climbing onto your chest when youâ€™re sleeping and purring for head pats. My own catâ€¦ well, heâ€™s not really the cuddly type. Most of the time he refuses to â€œstickâ€ with me. Whenever I pet him, I get the â€œugh, stop itâ€ face. (wipes tears)

Thereâ€™s also a hand-drawn sketch my friend made of my fursona holding Debbie and saying, â€œYou understand Mandarin???â€ because sometimes he really does respond to everything I say, as if he gets every word. Hahaha.

Dear Domino,

Alright â€” the clock is ticking.
Kikiâ€™s Delivery Service, candle lit, drink pouredâ€¦ Iâ€™m expecting a full report next time. And donâ€™t you dare try to slip past me with a one-sentence â€œit was nice.â€ I want your entire worldview rearranged on paper.

Your boyfriend sounds like the kind of person who turns â€œdomesticâ€ into something quietly cinematic. Nightcaps after burnout? Thatâ€™s dangerously close to a movie scene. And while you call him â€œslightly over-spoiled,â€ I think thatâ€™s just shorthand for â€œraised in an environment where kindness is instinct, not performance.â€ Iâ€™d argue thatâ€™s a rarer upbringing than people admit.

Your name story was a trip â€” Huang, Kevin, Domino. Itâ€™s like each one is a lens on a slightly different life, and you pick the one that fits the day. Domino feels like it carries a little mystery. Kevin feels like the easygoing friend. Huang feels like the last name that would appear in a bookâ€™s acknowledgements. I can see why you gravitate to Domino when you want distance from the noise.

You guessed my dadâ€™s in business â€” youâ€™re right. And I think you hit the nail on temperament. Heâ€™s a â€œwide netâ€ type, Iâ€™m a â€œquiet harpoonâ€ type. We move differently, but maybe weâ€™re fishing in the same ocean.

Your take on anchors hit me harder than I expected. Maybe â€œfinding the placeâ€ and â€œbecoming the version of yourself whoâ€™s ready to stayâ€ arenâ€™t separate â€” maybe they happen at the same time, like recognizing a face in the crowd only when youâ€™re in the right mood to look up.

Iâ€™ve been working remotely since I left my last job, which means I havenâ€™t â€œbumped intoâ€ anyone in ages. My sleeping scheduleâ€™s finally repairing itself, and funny enough, that small fix made the rest of my days flow better. Apparently one well-timed sunrise can fix more than coffee ever could.

Also â€” Iâ€™m glad youâ€™re taking that coastal road trip. Forget perfect skies; a little wind is what makes a trip stick in your memory. Justâ€¦ please send a sentence or two from the road. I donâ€™t care if itâ€™s about the sea or the pasta.

Until your Kiki review,
Moni

Dear Moni,

Okay okay â€” this is official.
Iâ€™m watching Kikiâ€™s Delivery Service today.
No more stalling, no more philosophical excuses. Iâ€™ll light a candle, pour a drink, and let Studio Ghibli quietly rearrange my worldview.
And if I donâ€™t mention it in my next letter, you have full permission to haunt me.

Now â€” about my boyfriend.
Heâ€™s a year older than me, tall and slim, and gives off this very â€œuniversity boyâ€ vibe â€” not just in appearance, but in how he speaks, moves, and thinks.
Sometimes I feel like heâ€™s still emotionally younger, in the best and strangest way. Maybe itâ€™s because he grew up in a really loving family â€” so loving, in fact, that heâ€™s been (just slightly) over-spoiled. But hey, Iâ€™m not complaining.
He treats me incredibly well. He takes care of meals, chores, mixes me a little nightcap when Iâ€™m burned outâ€¦ Heâ€™s warm, thoughtful, and honestly, I couldnâ€™t ask for more.

About my name â€”
Domino is the ID I use across most online spaces. Since Iâ€™m in China, my legal name is of course Chinese. My family name is Huang, which I sometimes use in formal or client settings.
When I was eleven, I gave myself the English name Kevin, and it stuck â€” friends from Thailand, Italy, and elsewhere all know me that way.
But between you and me, I think I prefer Domino.
It feels like a softer, slightly more comfortable version of myself. Not fake â€” justâ€¦ a little more distant from the noise of real life.

On what you said about your dad â€”
I had a bit of a reckless guess: is he in business? That kind of â€œwide circleâ€ approach feels like something that fits naturally in that world â€” cast a net, make connections, leave doors open.
But honestly, I donâ€™t think â€œmany friendsâ€ and â€œdeep friendsâ€ are opposites. Theyâ€™re just different stages of the same path: meet, observe, choose.
I doubt your dad is friends with literally everyone, and I doubt youâ€™d ever find your kindred spirits without meeting some new people first.
So maybe itâ€™s not really a difference in values â€” maybe itâ€™s just temperament. Two different ways of moving through the same social map.

What you said about anchorsâ€¦
Yeah. Maybe thirty years from now, Iâ€™ll pick a country, a city, a view â€” and finally stay put. But right now, I havenâ€™t found the place yet.
And more importantly, I havenâ€™t yet become the version of me whoâ€™s ready to stay.

Speaking of moving â€” I finalized my coastal road trip! Weâ€™re heading off this Saturday, fingers crossed for decent weather. Iâ€™m hoping for something cinematic: not perfect skies, but something with a little wind and drama.
(Also â€” pasta seems to appear at home today, though Iâ€™m pretty sure it is not going to come with white sauce. Still, a sign of progress.)

Your question about â€œsettling with someoneâ€ really made me pause.
I thinkâ€¦ for now, the answer is no.
A year and a half ago, I left this city to move up north and live with my boyfriend. We stayed there for a year, but eventually I realized the place wasnâ€™t right for either of us.
So I brought him back down with me. It cost time, energy, money â€” but I donâ€™t regret a single part of it.
To me, if someone really shares your rhythm, they wonâ€™t resist the road.
I donâ€™t want a love that keeps me in place. I want a love that moves with me.

Talk to you again soon â€” and that time, with my Kikiâ€™s Delivery Service review.

Your not-so-anchored friend,
Domino

Dear Domino,

Your line about â€œwe all eventually become the thing we once hatedâ€ really stuck with me. Iâ€™ve thought about that more times than Iâ€™d like to admit. Seeing flashes of your dad in yourself â€” even in something as small as the â€œdecision-makerâ€ role â€” is painfully relatable. I sometimes catch myself doing little things that echo my father, even though weâ€™ve always been so different.

And about what you said â€” if life ever brings us to the same city and we sit down for a drink (alcoholic or not), that honestly feels like one of those rare offers that stick in my mind. Not because of the drink, but because itâ€™s rare to hear someone say that and genuinely mean it. I admire that youâ€™d want to carry this connection into the real world. Most people keep pen-pal exchanges in a little bubble, but the fact that youâ€™re open to crossing that line makes this whole conversation feel a lot more real.

Also, youâ€™ve mentioned your boyfriend a few times in your letters â€” he sounds like he adds a lot of warmth and balance to your plans. Iâ€™m curious, whatâ€™s he like? And one more thing Iâ€™ve been meaning to ask â€” you always sign your letters as Domino. Is that the name you go by everywhere, or more like a pen-pal name you use here? I just realized I donâ€™t even know what you prefer to be called.

You already know my dad is an extrovert with a huge circle. I admire him for that, but Iâ€™ve always valued depth over breadth â€” fewer friends, but stronger bonds. Weâ€™ve clashed plenty over this. He thinks my quiet nature limits me, while I see it as a way to choose my connections with purpose. I guess in a way, weâ€™re both â€œdeciders,â€ just in different arenas. Maybe the challenge isnâ€™t escaping our parentsâ€™ traits, but learning how to own them without letting them own us.

About anchors â€” I feel the same way you do. Property, permanent roots, even the thought of staying in one place too longâ€¦ it feels like a door closing. My Odyssey is the opposite of that â€” itâ€™s a refusal to commit to one â€œharborâ€ too soon. But I think we both know that someday, there will be a place or a person that makes anchoring feel like the natural next step. Justâ€¦ not now.

As for Kikiâ€™s Delivery Service, itâ€™s almost poetic how it ties into this. Kiki leaves home not to settle, but to grow. She faces creative burnout, doubts herself, and even loses her ability to fly at one point. But in the end, itâ€™s not about finding a forever home â€” itâ€™s about regaining her balance and keeping herself in motion. Thatâ€™s why I think youâ€™d appreciate it â€” itâ€™s less about the magic and more about that quiet inner shift watch when you feel it's time.

Your coastal dilemma made me laugh because Iâ€™d be exactly the person to drive 10 hours just to see gray waves. Maybe thatâ€™s part of the charm â€” not every trip gives you â€œcrystal blue.â€ Sometimes you show up and the ocean is moody, and that becomes the memory you keep. (But if the pasta shows up first, Iâ€™ll consider that a fair trade) And hereâ€™s a wild fact: I havenâ€™t seen the sea in years. Not the gray waves, not the crystal ones. That will finally change when I start university in Alexandria â€” my first time living right by the coast.

Before I go, I want to flip your own question back to you. If you donâ€™t see yourself settling in one place for now, do you see yourself settling with someone? Or do you think that, like a city, people canâ€™t hold you in place either?

Your still-not-anchored friend,
Moni

P.S. Iâ€™m holding you accountable for watching Kikiâ€™s Delivery Service. No excuses.

Growing up with all that around you mustâ€™ve been fascinating. It makes me thinkâ€¦ being from such a background probably gives you a wider sense of the world from the very beginning.

Not to my hometown, not to school, not even to the broader idea of â€œhome.â€ Maybe itâ€™s because my dad spent most of my early years working in a different city? Iâ€™m not great at psychological self-analysis, but I suspect that might be part of it.

What I am sure of is that Iâ€™ve always had this restless hunger to see the world â€” to step into unfamiliar places, breathe in unfamiliar air, and collect little fragments of life from elsewhere.

I genuinely hope the citizenship and French visa (and maybe someday, the passport too) come through smoothly. The world needs more travelers with purpose.

Now, about that haunted villa â€”
You were really about to go just to send me pictures?? Thatâ€™s both incredibly sweet and slightly unhinged ğŸ˜­ Please donâ€™t feel like you owe me photographic proof from a place full of hobos, ghosts, and God knows what else.

That saidâ€¦ I am curious now.

Also, your Ghibli Sundays sound like the kind of ritual I didnâ€™t know I needed in my life. Pasta and animation â€” how could that go wrong?
