Hello DominoH,

I had to laugh at your â€œpyramids, sphinxes, camelsâ€ stereotype â€” no offense taken. Honestly, thatâ€™s what most people picture when they think of Egypt. Iâ€™m glad you researched Maadi, though, because youâ€™re right: itâ€™s not just postcard Egypt. Itâ€™s leafy streets, embassies tucked between old villas, the smell of fresh pastries mixing with Egyptian coffee, and a strange blend of languages on one block.

That being said, Iâ€™m originally from Sudan. Iâ€™ve only been living in Maadi for three years (almost four), so in a way, Iâ€™m still a foreigner here too. I might even be getting Egyptian citizenship soon, which is another step in this ongoing journey. I'm also thinking about studying in France, but after starting university here in Alexandria â€” a coastal governorate, just a couple of hours from Cairo â€” because transferring is easier than applying from the start. Hopefully, Iâ€™ll get the French passport eventually, making the odyssey more feasible.

Hereâ€™s a fact about me that might explain why I donâ€™t feel tied to just one country: my family history is full of crossings. My fatherâ€™s father was from Luxor, Egypt, but he moved to Sudan, where he met my grandmother, who was from Turkey. Iâ€™ve always found it fascinating how two people from such different places ended up meeting in a third country and choosing to settle there.
On my motherâ€™s side, the story is similar. Her maternal grandparents were from Mauritania, and her paternal grandparents were from India. So, as you can see, my family has been full of mixing. Maybe thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m drawn to so many places â€” Iâ€™ve never really been anchored to just one.

As for the urbex tripsâ€¦ plot twist: my little brother and cousin already visited the abandoned hospital without me. They said they couldnt wait till sunday but its the day im free from work they said they found lots of stray dogs were sleeping outside the hospital and they met some teenage boys from that area who advised them not to go inside or at least stay on the first floor because it was known to attract hobos, drug addicts, and maniacs. So yeah, they only checked out the first floor, but unfortunately, no photos or videos were taken. Now, thereâ€™s talk of exploring a famous haunted villa nearby. My little cousin claims he went in with friends once, and something inside chased them out â€” no words, just footsteps approaching. Honestly, Iâ€™m tempted to skip this oneâ€¦ but I promised you pictures, so Iâ€™ll stick to my word.

Your thoughts on the Odyssey meant a lot. Planting these â€œconnection seedsâ€ feels like half the adventure before the journey even begins. Iâ€™m already hearing back from some really interesting people across different countries â€” itâ€™s like my passport is collecting invisible stamps before Iâ€™ve even started the journey.

Speaking of passports, if you could pick a passport besides yours, what country would it be, and why

By the way, since youâ€™re into short films and layered storytelling, I have to ask â€” do you like Studio Ghibli movies? Theyâ€™re not exactly â€œshort,â€ but their pacing, visuals, and subtle details always feel like lessons in cinema. Iâ€™m curious if youâ€™ve ever drawn inspiration from them. I started a ritual on Sunday, where I pick a Studio Ghibli film and watch it, but beforehand, I cook a comfort meal (my favorite is chicken pasta with white sauce; hereâ€™s the recipe: https://talkingmeals.com/white-sauce-chicken-pasta-recipe/). Unlike traditional snacks, I gotta say Studio Ghibli movies arenâ€™t like others â€” theyâ€™re more complex. They create strong character personalities, and they might not be linear or easy to understand most of the time, but theyâ€™re truly one-of-a-kind experiences. I still didn't finish a lot of them until now, but my favourite so far is their 2nd film, CASTLE IN THE SKY. God, I love that movie so so so so so much. Their movies make you feel like a kid again, not because theyâ€™re meant for kids, but because theyâ€™re so fascinating, like reminiscing about that Disney movie you watched with your mom when you were little. I highly recommend watching their films if you haven't already, but donâ€™t watch the English dub â€” go for the original Japanese version with subtitles. Iâ€™m so mad at myself for missing out on these masterpieces all this time.

Looking forward to your reply (and Iâ€™ll try not to send back too many haunted pictures next Sunday).

Warmest regards,
Moni

Hello Domino,

Your canyon shot stuck with me â€” I can see it like a frame from a film. Wide lens, horizon swallowing everything, and there you areâ€¦ small in scale but anchored in the moment. I think you just described not only your worldview but also why your work has that layered pull.

I like how your life goal mirrors mine in a way. You want to capture the earthâ€™s raw beauty; I want to see it through human connection. Same planet, two lenses. And that line about â€œnot everyone, just the earth in its purest formâ€ â€” thatâ€™s poetry, even if you didnâ€™t mean it to be.

Your urbex approach actually makes a lot of sense. I think people imagine explorers as reckless, but in reality, calculated exploration takes just as much courage, maybe more. Youâ€™re scouting with precision, almost like a director planning a scene before shooting. Speaking of urbex, I have something funny â€” next Sunday, my little brother and my cousin want to explore an abandoned hospital 30 minutes away from our area. Iâ€™m not really into exploring abandoned places myself, but Iâ€™m going along just to keep an eye on them (and make sure they donâ€™t get into trouble). Iâ€™ll send you pictures from it. Who knows, maybe Iâ€™ll gain a new appreciation for this whole urbex thing.

Since you like landscapes, Iâ€™ll give you a little snapshot of where I live. Iâ€™m in Maadi â€” one of Cairoâ€™s greener, quieter neighborhoods. Itâ€™s full of tall trees, old villas, and small streets that feel worlds away from the chaos of downtown Cairo. It's full of foreigners from all over the globe. Walk down the road and youâ€™ll hear 5 languages being spoken in the span of an afternoonâ€” itâ€™s really fascinating. But beneath that, itâ€™s still distinctly Egyptian, with small cafÃ©s, street food stalls, and kids playing football in alleys.

As for my Odyssey â€” Iâ€™m laying the groundwork now while Iâ€™m still in Egypt. My idea is to have letters and friendships scattered like pins across the globe before I set off. That way, when I finally reach each country, Iâ€™m not arriving cold. Thereâ€™s already a person, a story, waiting for me there. It turns the trip into something much more alive.

And I have to say â€” you calling me â€œMoniâ€ already feels like youâ€™ve fast-forwarded the friendship a bit. Iâ€™ll take it. ğŸ˜‰

Looking forward to your next letter â€” and maybe hearing what landscapes are at the very top of your list.

Moni

But I do love traveling. One of my personal life goals is to earn enough money to see all the breathtaking natural landscapes this planet has to offer. Not everything, not everyone â€” just the earth in its purest form.

Also, thank you â€” really â€” for reading through my profile so attentively. Or was it my letter? Either way, I appreciate the thoughtful curiosity.
About the short films: recently, Iâ€™ve been leaning toward telling compact stories using relatively polished cinematography. You probably noticed my little involvement in the furry fandom â€” sometimes I let furry characters take the lead role in my videos. Itâ€™s fun, a bit theatrical, and allows for some layered storytelling without showing my actors' actual face.

When it comes to urbex, Iâ€™m honestly not the wild, spontaneous type whoâ€™ll just hop fences or crawl through drain pipes at 3 a.m. My anxiety wouldnâ€™t survive that. Iâ€™m very result-driven, and the idea of wandering without a destination makes me uncomfortable. So most of my urbex trips are to places already scouted by others â€” shut-down factories, half-finished buildings, wartime bunkers lost to history, or overgrown railroads.
But then again, if Iâ€™m driving and happen to spot an abandoned place by chanceâ€¦ I might just swerve the wheel and detour on impulse. I guess a small part of me wants to be spontaneous.

I used to be more physically active as a kid, but honestly now? Iâ€™m kind of a couch creature. Not a fan of most sports, which means Iâ€™ve gained a bit of weight these years. Maybe I do need to take a page from your book and find a sport that at least gets my body moving again.

If I had to describe my worldview in a single camera shotâ€¦ I think it would go like this:
The scene is on the edge of a canyon â€” maybe the Grand Canyon, or something similarly vast and awe-striking (I always forget the names). My car is parked slightly off-angle at the cliffâ€™s edge. Iâ€™m leaning on the hood with a camera in hand. The lens is ultra wide. The shot captures the immensity of the ridges and rock folds in front of meâ€¦ and in contrast, just how small I am. Me and the Earth â€” in the same frame.

Looking forward to hearing more about how youâ€™re planning your Odyssey.
And if I get a second letter from youâ€¦ Iâ€™m totally calling you Moni next time ğŸ˜‰

Warm regards,
Domino

Nice to meet you! Oh your work looks really cool! It's not exactly the same thing but I used to dream of being a director or screenwriter. Would you like your life to be more exciting?

Isn't furry fandom a kind of Cosplay but in general animal characters? ( Sorry I'm not very well informed.). Sometimes I wonder what's wrong with me, why I'm not interested in the same things as everyone else.

I feel that the fact that I can't be 100% myself with people creates distance between them and me.

Daily life here in Mali depends on what kind of person you are. If you're a social person, then you'll love life here, because here life is communal, everyone knows each other in the neighbourhood, people form little groups in front of their houses, to chat, have a good time together etc...
But if you're an introvert like me it's just hell haha, if you don't get out of the house too much and you're not the type to talk to everyone in the neighborhood, people take it badly, you're seen as something haughty. A lot of people idealize community life, and I find it horrible sometimes because it's intolerant of difference.

Here we eat a lot of rice with different sauces, and weekends are like everywhere else I suppose, people go out with their friends, relax or work...

Hi,
I'm Lamine, 24 and I live in Mali.
At the moment I'm going through a bit of a strange time in my life, in truth I think it's always been like that haha. But just recently I decided to delete the social network account I have (Instagram and LinkedIn), I don't really use them but I wasn't afraid to delete these accounts because it was like they were my only link to the outside world.

I've always tried to escape loneliness, yet it chases me no matter what I do, no matter where I go. It's always right there, right around the corner! Someone somewhere in this world will read this letter, and I want to say thank you to that person and, above all, have a wonderful time.
